history.narrative: Law 12-52, the “Nuisance Repairs Amendment Act of 1997,” was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 12-174, which was referred to the Committee on Consumer and Regulatory Affairs. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on September 8, 1997, and September 22, 1997, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on October 3, 1997, it was assigned Act No. 12-169 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review. D.C. Law 12-52 became effective on February 27, 1998.

ACT 12-169 IN THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA OCTOBER 3, 1997 Codification District of Columbia Code 1998 Supp. To amend section 1 of An Act To provide for the abatement of nuisances in the District of Columbia, and for other purposes, to require owners of real property that have become a nuisance to pay fair market value for repairs made to the property by the District of Columbia government. BE IT ENACTED BY THE COUNCIL OF THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, That this act may be cited as the "Nuisance Repairs Amendment Act of 1997 Sec. 2. Section l(a) of An Act To provide for the abatement of nuisances in the District of Columbia by the Commissioners of said District, and for other purposes, approved April 14, 1906 (34 Stat. 114; D.C. Code § 5-513(a is amended by striking the phrase "assess the cost of correcting such condition" and inserting the phrase "assess the fair market value of the correction of the condition or the actual cost of the correction, whichever is higher in its place. Sec. 3. Fiscal impact statement. As before, the cost of correcting the nuisance will be paid by the owner, presumably, so there is no added cost to the District. It can be expected, however, that there will be an increase in litigation costs preceding the District’s effort to abate the nuisances. The legislation does not address who pays this cost, but it can be presumed that it will be added to the cost of abating the nuisance itself. The revenue to be raised by correcting the nuisances will be offset by an equal amount of cost to the agency doing the correcting. Currently, there isn’t any historical data which will predict how many nuisances will reach this level, so the amount of potential cost and revenue to and for that agency cannot be estimated. The Financial Plan and Budget will be impacted by a like amount of revenues and expenditures if the proposed legislation is implemented to the letter, however, neither can be quantified at this time.
